Award.AwardTitle: 2018 Summer Program on Game Theory and Economics; July 16 - July 20 and July 22 - July 23, 2018; Stony Brook, New York

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds a 2018 workshop in game theory and applications of game theory. The conference, follow-on workshops, and lectures are held each summer as a coordinated program designed to bring together a distinguished group of senior scientists from around the globe with junior faculty and graduate students from across the U.S. Topics include new developments in game theory, areas in the intersection between game theory and computer science (such as Computation and Privacy), and applications of game theory to business and public policy. The activities advance science by giving young scholars the opportunity to form new research collaborations and present their work to a distinguished audience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary outcome of the project was the promotion of intensive interaction between young and established researchers from all over the world, in the field of Game Theory and its applications, mainly to economics. During the life of the award, the center held the 29th International Conference on Game Theory (more than 250 participants) and the Workshop on Stopping Time Problems in Game Theory, Economics, and Finance (50 participants). Significant cutting-edge results in game theory and its applications were presented and discussed. Many young researchers had an opportunity to present their work and to get feedback from senior scholars.

The project contributed to the interaction between scholars, with emphasis on advanced graduate students, junior and senior researchers. Its goal was to foster a better understanding of the most recent results in the area of Game Theory and its applications in various fields. Among these fields are auctions, bargaining, industrial organization, experimental economics, social and political models, cooperative games, fairness, voting, learning and evolution, bounded rationality, matching, mechanism design, stopping time problems in game theory and finance, applications of dynamic games, and contracts.

The project had a strong interdisciplinary orientation. Besides economics and mathematics, the conferences and workshops dealt with issues in computer science, political science, and experimental behavior.
